feed.title: Survivor Interview: Jim Rice and Keith Tollefson
feed.subtitle: Find out why they will never respect Cochran and how religion came to dominate both the show and its participants.

content.div:
On last week's episode of Survivor: South Pacific, Keith Tollefson and Jim Rice became the first casualties of the new merged Te Tuna tribe. The season's first double elimination wasn't orchestrated by former members of the opposing Upolu tribe; instead, they fell victim to Harvard law student John Cochran's turn-coat maneuver in the tie-breaking rock draw. Add that to Tollefson's rumoured affair with secretly married fellow cast member Whitney Duncan (a subject we were told we could not ask about), and it's understandable that both he and Rice were in an especially excitable mood when they sat down to talk to Dose.ca. Find out why they will never respect Cochran and how religion came to dominate both the show and its participants.

Both your eliminations were more or less a result of Cochran switching allegiances to save himself.

Jim Rice: What was really surprising about what happened is if you're playing to win you know how many votes you need on the jury. And if you're thinking that far ahead, which anybody who wants to win should be, then if you flip on your tribe at that point in the game there are five people who aren't going to vote for you. You can do without two votes but you can't do without five votes. You need five votes to win. So having that game knowledge that Keith and I both have is why he and I were willing to go to [the] rocks [draw]. Because in our minds we knew that if we didn't stay strong one tribe would pick the other one apart. And that's exactly what happened.

Keith Tollefson: It's Survivor 101. We should have stayed strong as a tribe and we should have made plays at individual members of their tribe. Dawn had made a play at Rick because of the Mormon connection; I could have made a play at Albert. In the end I feel that Cochran would have flipped no matter what because he would have never let himself draw rocks, because of the self-preservation aspect, not based on strategy.

Do either of you have a begrudging respect for Cochran's game-playing ability?

JR: Respect and Cochran will never go in the same sentence for me. And I really mean that, that's not even a joke. I feel sorry for the guy on an everyday basis. I have no respect for him whatsoever.

KT: It wasn't a move!

JR: A move would have been to tell us, "Hey guys, if I flip I'm screwed. I know that but I'm not drawing rocks." Tell us that and we'll give you the [immunity] idol!

KT: Exactly, that's a smart move because we would have given him the idol right then and there.

JR: Whitney or Dawn, who both have more balls than Cochran, would have drawn rocks. No, I have no respect for him on a personal or game level.

Jim, you referred to the remaining Upolu members and Cochran as a cult. Do you stand by that?

JR: I think a cult is a good way to put it. Even aside from the things that were broadcast they were drinking the Kool Aid. It's like they forgot that it was Survivor and Coach had them convinced that anything they did that was dishonourable would haunt them for the rest of their lives, for the rest of the game.

You mentioned religion earlier. It seems to be playing a very big role in this season.

JR: (laughs) Yeah, it was even more prevalent than it comes across [on screen]. It sickened me when I saw, two or three episodes ago, Coach praying to find the idol when he already had the idol. I'm like, ‘Alright, you can pray and do the thing but you really want to bring it into the game like that?' I think it made him look foolish.

Did you ever feel excluded as a result?

JR: No, because it really was an us versus them cult. I think Whitney put it really well when she said, ‘I pray too and I'm not a bad person.' And I think that praying to find an idol in a game show is a little off.

KT: Brendon was the one main person who was getting into prayers and then Coach fed into that, making them feel safe because of their religious background. So when he prayed for that idol and Brendon said, ‘Thank the Lord, the Lord has answered our prayers,' it really was a sad thing to see. Coach was playing him based on his religion

JR: One lunatic is a little bit silly -- you start putting a couple of lunatics together and things start to get scary.

Jond@Dose.ca

link.Abstract: Now safely away from Redemption Island, the teacher from New York State tells us about life on the outside looking in and why she feels she became so beloved so fast.

link.Abstract: As the second contestant sent to Redemption Island, Christine Shields Markoski made it through an astonishing five elimination challenges before Ozzy's power play knocked her out -- one week short of returning to the game.
